1109050925958729729.text: Old Man Yells at Awards: a rant (icymi)https://twitter.com/LorenzoPilia/status/1108807210652585985 …

1108808479349841925.text: This is something I've been thinking about for a while (I'm even collecting examples in Evernote!), would love to hear other opinions, both from native and non-native English speakers

1108807217850003456.text: I understand where this is coming from, no hard feelings (for now!), but we need to start pointing this out when we see it, and IGF is just the latest and most noticeable example

1108807216239468544.text: I lived in UK and I know well how Brits tend to take less seriously / be dismissive of non-native speakers – even the nice ones are often biased, without fully realising it

1108807215262154752.text:
If you keep awarding, featuring, inviting to talk / exhibit / participate in bundles etc. mostly people from English-speaking countries... you're either

• Lazy

• A native-English speaker yourself and probably don't fully realise the issue

1108807213639000065.text: Until a while ago you could have said "ok, but there's not much going on in other countries / the quality of work there is lower" and to some extent I would have agreed with you, but now that's no longer the case

1108807211827036160.text: We really need to start talking about how developers from America and other English-speaking countries tend to be the ones who are most often celebrated

1108807210652585985.text: Uuuuh another thing about IGF I just noticed, not sure if someone already brought it up: every award this year (except for Student and Audience) went to American or US-based developers

1108732015745122304.text: In any case: congratulations to @BreakinBahiyya @VQ_Flusk @clairemeekel for winning the IGF Student award with after HOURS – you deserved more

1108732013178249221.text: I’m genuinly curious to know if these things are ever discussed, or if they’re that way just because they’ve always been that way

1108732010200219650.text: I mean, in most cases the Grand Prize winners and nominees are games which are already popular, or made by established teams, $30K is not going to make that much of a difference to them, compared to student teams or Nuovo award nominees...

1108731993435582464.text: IGF Grand Prize gets $30K, Student award (and all other categories) gets $3K – wouldn’t it made more sense to swap the two?https://twitter.com/igfnews/status/1108559007998853120?s=21 …

1093185348476305408.text: So, the reason why the organisers ask you to book your own travel could be that they don't have much cash available before the event takes place. But if this is not feasible for you, try talking clearly with them, if they really want you there they will find a solution.

1093185347322867722.text: This doesn't apply to all events of course, but for smaller / independent ones that's often the case, unless they're receiving public funding – and in some cases, even that only arrives after the event is over!

1093185346001612801.text: Looking at this from the organiser's side: many attendees tend to buy their ticket shortly before the event, sponsorships often arrive late, or after an event has ended... at the same time, venue rent needs to be payed in advancehttps://twitter.com/ChellaRamanan/status/1093112303623516162 …

1084434029854769153.text: Of course with more time available you can make a bigger / more polished game, but this is not always true, and in most cases it's not really worth the extra time investment

1084434028219023360.text:
Most people can't take the entire weekend off to work on a game, because of reasons such as:

• Health
• Family commitments 
• Full time job

So... if you want to make your jam more accessible (why wouldn't you?), think about length too

1084434026734276608.text: Game jams don't have to be 48-72 hours long! The 8 hour jam format is very common in Berlin, one big advantage is that it allows a broader audience to participatehttps://twitter.com/joonturbo/status/1084424114033577986 …

1082339247271698433.text: Aaaaaand... that's it? I can't share numbers for each single project, but I hope this was still useful – feel free to ask questions here, via DM or anonymously on Curious Cathttps://curiouscat.me/LorenzoPilia

1082339245887492101.text: What I'm less happy about is that last year I was so busy working for clients, that I had little time / mental capacity to work on and develop my own projects... that should be the point of going freelance, right?

1082339244025278464.text: Overall I'm happy with the quality and variety of the work I've done in 2018, and I think I was paid fairly. The last full time job I had (as a product manager in a startup) back in 2013/14 was paying more though... but money is not the point of going freelance, right?

1082339241781350403.text: Publishing the ads still requires a bit of manual work, but overall it's something I wouldn't mind getting more of, I really don't like to spend my time chasing new clients though

1082339240619458560.text: I often dream about passive income, the only thing closer to that are the job ads I promote through @berlingamez (and associated channels / events), which last year generated 1.400 € – I ask 50 to 100 € per ad

1082339238027452417.text: We all like to make fun of blockchain, but it kinda saved my ass last year – also I got to work on bullshit-free blockchain stuff (no cryptocurrency) and met some nice people, I definitely respect and understand the whole space more

1082339237071065089.text:
Income source, by topic:

1/3 Game events

1/3 Blockchain events

1/3 Other events (tech-related)

1082339235821162496.text:
The lesson here: if you have money, it's easier to make more money 

(Meaning: in a different position, where I needed the money, I wouldn't have dared to ask that much)

1082339233703120898.text: Since I wasn't sure I wanted to do that job (the exact details weren't even that clear), and I already had enough other paid projects going on at the time, I decided to ask way more than I normally do... and ended up getting it!

1082339232008597505.text: I was extremely busy when that request came along, and it didn't seem like a good match (mainstream gaming stuff), so my immediate reaction was to decline... I then thought it was worth finding out more about it, so agreed to have a chat

1082339230284697600.text: Only one job came "out of nowhere", through an advertising agency that found me on Meetup (my investment in a LinkedIn Premium account doesn't seem to have paid off, got zero leads from that)

1082339227906527232.text: Half of the jobs were returning annual gigs I already did in previous years, the other half came through personal or professional contacts / recommendations

1082339226929246211.text: A friend asked how many days I worked last year... I'd say 5 days a week, and took 20 days of holiday. Was lucky I almost never got sick.

1082339224332980224.text: One of the things I appreciate the most about freelancing is being able to work with different people on different topics, but 6 parallel projects are definitely too much

1082339223406022657.text: I mention the unpaid stuff, because at some point last summer I had 6 different projects running in parallel I had to take care of

1082339221707341825.text:
Most of the money in 2018 came from 8 different events + 1 research project.

I've also organised / been involved in 15 other shorter events / meetups where there was little or no money.

1082339219975168007.text: After writing this yesterday, I've been thinking about it and... maybe I should have charged more than 500 €, considering my experience and profile? This is why transparency matters – if I had known what other people in my field / city charge, I could have acted accordingly.

1082339217823408128.text: I was scared of asking that amount initially (is it too much? am I worth that?), but eventually after the first client said "ok" I started believing in it and learn to say the amount with a serious face, while doing eye contact... usually people trust you that way

1082339216615489537.text: In 2018 I had to come up for the first time with a daily rate for event production, previously I always agreed on a fixed fee for each project. Finding a number wasn't easy! Ultimately I decided to go for 500 € / day.

1082339214845505536.text: Financially 2018 has been my best year as a freelancer, I made twice as much as I did in 2017, and 30% more than I did in 2016 – if you're a freelancer, or if you have a business, you know numbers go up and down

1082339213113257985.text: In 2018 I've invoiced a total of 43.000 €. This is gross, before taxes. Also worth mentioning that health insurance is mandatory in Germany, in my case it's around 500 € / month (the amount is calculated based on much you earn).

1082339211376775168.text: I work as a freelance event producer, curator & host – tech conferences and festivals basically. I've been doing this for 5 years, and did other jobs during the previous decade (project management, graphic design).

1082339209669685248.text:
Basic info about myself, for context:

— Male
— White
— Able-bodied
— 36 years old
— Based in Berlin, Germany
— Favourite colour: yellow

1082339207845212162.text: Side note: it's interesting how these days lots of people are very open to talk about personal, intimate stuff, but money is still a big taboo... try asking someone what their salary is, or how much money they have in the bank, and see how they react!
